child.publications: Lewis, M. Paul (ed.). 2009. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 16 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/home.asp. (15 February, 2011.)

child.pub-comments: "The border between Koryak and Alutor [alr] has not yet been defined. Chachuve (Northern Koryak) and Alutor are now separated. Alutor at one time was considered a dialect of Koryak. The classification of the other dialects is unclear. The Chavchuven, Palan, and Kamen dialects are apparently not inherently intelligible (Ethnologue 2009).
child.geography: Russian Federation (Asia): Koryak National Okrug, south of the Chukchi [ckt]; Kamchatka Peninsula north half and adjacent continent.

child.pub-comments: "Considered a dialect of Koryak [kpy] until recently" (Ethnologue 2009).
child.geography: Russian Federation (Asia): Koryak National District, northeast Kamchatka Peninsula, Vyvenka and Khailino villages; 2 families in Rekinniki; families in Tilichiki and Tymlat; some scattered.
child.publications: Lewis, M. Paul (ed.). 2009. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 16 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/home.asp. (15 February, 2011.)

child.pub-comments: "No known speakers. There were 200 to 400 in 1900 but language now has no remaining speakers. Ethnic population: 8." "Formerly considered a dialect of Chukchi [ckt]" (Ethnologue 2009).
child.geography: Russian Federation (Asia): Cape Navarin; Chukchi villages.
child.publications: Lewis, M. Paul (ed.). 2009. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 16 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/home.asp. (15 February, 2011.)

child.pub-comments: "Closely related to Alutor [air], Kerek [krk] and Koryak [kpy]. Itelmen [itl] is more distantly related. Chukchi may be mutually intelligible with some varieties of Koryak [kpy] (1988 Comrie)" (Ethnologue 2009).
